Interaction Mode

Systems and mechanics for roleplaying and social encounters

When your game focuses on conversations, negotiations, gathering information, or building relationships with NPCs, you're in Interaction Mode. This mode encompasses all social aspects of D&D.

Core Systems for Interaction

Social Interaction

The primary system for this mode:

  • NPC Attitudes: Hostile, Unfriendly, Indifferent, Friendly, Helpful
  • Social Skills: Persuasion, Deception, Intimidation, Insight
  • Influence: Changing NPC attitudes and gathering information
  • Conversation Structure: Turn-based or free-form social encounters

Languages

Communication and understanding:

  • Common Languages: Common, Dwarvish, Elvish, Giant, etc.
  • Exotic Languages: Abyssal, Celestial, Draconic, Infernal
  • Secret Languages: Druidic, Thieves' Cant

Skills & Ability Checks

Relevant social skills:

  • Charisma Skills: Persuasion, Deception, Intimidation, Performance
  • Wisdom Skills: Insight, Animal Handling
  • Intelligence Skills: History, Religion (for cultural knowledge)

Typical Interaction Scenarios

  • Negotiation: Bargaining for better prices, making deals
  • Persuasion: Convincing NPCs to help, change their mind, or reveal information
  • Deception: Lying, disguising intentions, bluffing
  • Intimidation: Threatening, coercing, or frightening NPCs
  • Insight: Reading intentions, detecting lies, understanding motivations
  • Gathering Information: Asking questions, investigating rumors
  • Building Relationships: Making allies, gaining trust, forming bonds

Transitioning Out of Interaction Mode

Interaction mode typically transitions to:

  • Combat Mode: When negotiations fail and initiative is rolled
  • Exploration Mode: When leaving a social scene to investigate or travel
  • Downtime Mode: When beginning long-term relationship building
